paragraphs.text: #YouTubeAsksObama: GOP desperately needs a 'Glozell' moment.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Republicans who mock President Obama's interviews with the three popular YouTube Internet stars make a serious mistake
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Obama White House is completely incompetent and weak
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they know how to spin everyday Americans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Washington media crowd, including conservative media, preaches to the choir of news junkies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The idea that you can win a modern presidential election without being modern is what should be mocked
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How can it be that some Republicans still don't understand that young people aren't watching"Meet the Press" or "Fox News Sunday"?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: news junkies are watching less"Meet the Press."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Young people are getting their news from YouTube, Facebook and Ellen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And Team Obama has largely monopolized the playgrounds where Millennials are hanging out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The YouTube interviews inside the White House were an easy home run for the president's communications team
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The White House must love the ridiculing they are getting from conservatives, too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The more out of touch Republicans seem, the easier their job to spin young people becomes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Internet stars who interviewed Obama have a combined reach of thirteen million people
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: - and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: most of them aren't following politics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They are 'gettable'
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Democrats are reaching them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Republicans need to change their elitist attitudes -- and fast
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Voters aren't as informed as we want them to be
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Democrats have figured out how to reach them with simple messages
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I am not sure how anyone could criticize the president's outreach to thirteen million people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After all
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: one YouTube host informed the president that during the State of the Union address, the most Googled question in America was"How old is Obama?"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Hank Green, a wildly successful vlogger with his brother, who regularly reaches 2.4 million people through their YouTube videos, started off the round-robin interviews by thanking the president for welcoming him to his house
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Obama, showing incredible connectivity with his audience responded with an analogy that every young person understands
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "I'm actually leasing (this house), and my lease runs out in two years. I hope to get my security deposit back," said Obama
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Green, who was born in 1980, focused his questions on what young, non-news junkies are thinking about their government
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Green asked whether something can "really get done in Washington," how drone strikes make sense and whether or not more sanctions can work on a country like North Korea
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: His questioning was serious
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Green also asked one of the smartest questions Obama has had over the last six years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Green told the president,"I don't smoke pot... I think it's bad for my brain... but I'm for legalization.... how do we move forward out of this legal gray-ness?"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It was a way of forming a question many in the White House press corps have never thought about
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Green finished the interview by sharing with Obama a receipt for a prescription drug medication that he said cost $1,100 but because he enrolled in ObamaCare now costs $5
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The moment was a strong message for the millions watching
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The president didn't miss the moment either and said of ObamaCare,"We had some bad hiccups initially... but the website works really well now."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Glozell Simon, a 52-year-old comedian who goes by the name Glozell Green and reaches 3 million people, was up next
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Glozell surprised the Washington crowd by first asking,"Why didn't the government help Sony feel protected and safe enough to release the film on time?"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: She went on to tell the president she cut off the hoodies from her husband's sweatshirts because of her concern for his safety
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: then asked a question about Cuba because many of her Cuban friends have concerns over Obama's new friendship with Castro
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Glozell, who although is wildly creative and funny, was completely respectful of the situation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: She asked about same sex marriage and Obama's legacy and gave her followers a peek at the president answering easy, soft questions
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The president looked and sounded relatable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Bethany Mota, a 19-year-old YouTube star who regularly reaches eight million people was the last interviewer
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Mota also asked informal but serious questions on education, cyber-bullying, Boko Haram and China
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Obama told her,"your voice is more powerful than the president of the United States."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And I am sure her young female followers agreed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Mota, too, asked the president a question in a way traditional reporters have failed to ask
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "I was just in China and couldn't access the apps and websites I could back home," Mota said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Obama gave her a non-answer that made him look knowledgeable but likeable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: She also said,"I never really followed politics that much... why should the younger generation be interested in politics?"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The president again spun a good tale about the need for young people to get involved so they can go to college
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Eight million young women now think Obama wants them to go to college
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It was a brilliant move by the president
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Obama finished the round of interviews by taking a selfie with the three and adding this eye-opening insight into his reason for going around the White House press corps and sitting down with YouTube stars
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Obama told them:"This is the power of what the Internet is all about... you can create content and there' s not all these barriers to entry... suddenly you get millions of people who are listening to you."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Republicans are bound to lose the next presidential election again if they can't communicate with new voters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Millions of people walk into the voting booth and vote for someone they like
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: News junkies and Washington types casually refer to this as"Who would you want to have a beer with?"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The sentiment is accurate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the analogy should be updated to"Who do you want to make a YouTube video with?"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I think President Obama is weak, bored with the office, and an incompetent leader
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But he sure knows how to go around the White House press corps
paragraphs.label: assumption
